messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 48 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: The Complexity of Order-Finding for ROABPs

Paper Abstract: Abstract We study the order-finding problem for Read-once Oblivious Algebraic Branching Programs (ROABPs). Given a polynomial f𝑓f and a parameter w𝑤w, the goal is to find an order σ𝜎\sigma in which f𝑓f has an ROABP of width w𝑤w. We show that this problem is 𝖭𝖯𝖭𝖯\mathsf{NP}-hard in the worst case, even when the input is a constant degree polynomial that is given in its dense representation. We provide a reduction from 𝙲𝚞𝚝𝚆𝚒𝚍𝚝𝚑𝙲𝚞𝚝𝚆𝚒𝚍𝚝𝚑\mathtt{CutWidth} to prove these results. Owing to the exactness of our reduction, all the known results for the hardness of approximation of 𝙲𝚞𝚝𝚆𝚒𝚍𝚝𝚑𝙲𝚞𝚝𝚆𝚒𝚍𝚝𝚑\mathtt{CutWidth} also transfer directly to the order-finding problem. Additionally, we also show that any constant-approximation algorithm for the order-finding problem would imply a polynomial time approximation scheme (PTAS) for it. On the algorithmic front, we design algorithms that solve the order-finding problem for generic ROABPs in polynomial time, when the width w𝑤w is polynomial in the individual degree d𝑑d of the polynomial f𝑓f. That is, our algorithm is efficient for most/random ROABPs, and requires more time only on a lower-dimensional subspace (or subvariety) of ROABPs. Even when the individual degree is constant, our algorithm runs in time nO​(log⁡w)superscript𝑛𝑂𝑤n^{O(\log w)} for most/random ROABPs. This stands in strong contrast to the case of (Boolean) ROBPs, where only heuristic order-finding algorithms are known.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 48 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 48"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Hitting-Sets for ROABP and Sum of Set-Multilinear Circuits",
        "Inapproximability Results for Maximum Edge Biclique, Minimum Linear Arrangement, and Sparsest Cut",
        "Inapproximability of Treewidth, One-Shot Pebbling, and Related Layout Problems",
        "Equivalence of-algebras and cubic forms",
        "NP-Hardness of Testing Equivalence to Sparse Polynomials and to Constant-Support Polynomials",
        "Polynomial formulations as a barrier for reduction-based hardness proofs",
        "Learning Generalized Depth Three Arithmetic Circuits in the Non-Degenerate Case",
        "Graph-Based Algorithms for Boolean Function Manipulation",
        "Reconstruction algorithms for low-rank tensors and depth-3 multilinear circuits",
        "Explicit Commutative ROABPs from Partial Derivatives",
        "The complexity of boolean formula minimization",
        "Improving the variable ordering of OBDDs is NP-complete",
        "Learning Arithmetic Formulas in the Presence of Noise: A General Framework and Applications to Unsupervised Learning",
        "On Hardness of Testing Equivalence to Sparse Polynomials Under Shifts",
        "Ideals, Varieties and Algorithms",
        "Demystifying the border of depth-3 algebraic circuits",
        "Deterministic Identity Testing Paradigms for Bounded Top-Fanin Depth-4 Circuits",
        "A Probabilistic Remark on Algebraic Program Testing",
        "A survey of graph layout problems",
        "Quasipolynomial-Time Identity Testing of Non-commutative and Read-Once Oblivious Algebraic Branching Programs",
        "Hitting sets for multilinear read-once algebraic branching programs, in any order",
        "Computers and Intractability; A Guide to the Theory of NP-Completeness",
        "Identity Testing for Constant-Width, and Commutative, Read-Once Oblivious ABPs",
        "Learning sums of powers of low-degree polynomials in the non-degenerate case",
        "Deterministic Identity Testing for Sum of Read-once Oblivious Arithmetic Branching Programs",
        "Tensor Rank is NP-Complete",
        "NP-Hardness of Learning Programs and Partial MCSP",
        "NP-hardness of Minimum Circuit Size Problem for OR-AND-MOD Circuits",
        "The Minimum Formula Size Problem is (ETH) Hard",
        "Efficient algorithms for some special cases of the polynomial equivalence problem",
        "Separation between Read-once Oblivious Algebraic Branching Programs (ROABPs) and Multilinear Depth Three Circuits",
        "Learning Restricted Models of Arithmetic Circuits",
        "Reconstruction of non-degenerate homogeneous depth three circuits",
        "Superpolynomial Lower Bounds Against Low-Depth Algebraic Circuits",
        "Some NP-complete set covering problems",
        "Dimension-dependent bounds for Gröbner bases of polynomial ideals",
        "Min cut is NP-complete for edge weighted trees",
        "Algorithms and Data Structures in VLSI Design: OBDD-foundations and applications",
        "Psuedorandom Generators for Space-Bounded Computation",
        "Lower bounds for non-commutative computation",
        "Über höhere Kongruenzen",
        "Separation of Multilinear Circuit and Formula Size",
        "Deterministic polynomial identity testing in non-commutative models",
        "Fast Probabilistic Algorithms for Verification of Polynomial Identities",
        "How hard is the tensor rank?",
        "The nonapproximability of OBDD minimization",
        "Branching programs and binary decision diagrams: theory and applications",
        "Probabilistic algorithms for sparse polynomials"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 48 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in The Complexity of Order-Finding for ROABPs, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
